title: Multiple Navbar Sections
text:
QuartoDocBuilder supports multiple dropdown sections in the navbar, similar to Rhino documentation. This allows you to organize your documentation into logical categories like “Tutorials”, “Explanation”, and “How-to Guides”.


To create multiple sections, use the sections field in QuartoConfig:
using QuartoDocBuilder

config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "user/MyPackage.jl",

    # Define multiple sections - each gets a dropdown in the navbar
    sections = [
        SectionConfig(
            title = "Tutorials",
            dir = "tutorials",
            desc = "Step-by-step guides to get started.",
            order = 1
        ),
        SectionConfig(
            title = "Explanation",
            dir = "explanation",
            desc = "Understand how things work.",
            order = 2
        ),
        SectionConfig(
            title = "How-to Guides",
            dir = "how-to",
            desc = "Task-oriented guides.",
            order = 3
        )
    ]
)

quarto_build_site(config)












Field
Type
Default
Description




title
String
required
Display title in navbar


dir
String
“”
Directory containing .qmd files


desc
String
“”
Description for the section index page


dropdown
Bool
true
Show as dropdown menu


dropdown_limit
Int
15
Max items before falling back to index link


index_file
String
“”
Custom index file name (defaults to {dir}.qmd)


sidebar
Bool
true
Show sidebar when browsing this section


order
Int
100
Position in navbar (lower = more left)






When you define sections, create corresponding directories:
docs/
├── tutorials/
│   ├── getting-started.qmd
│   ├── basic-usage.qmd
│   └── advanced.qmd
├── explanation/
│   ├── architecture.qmd
│   └── how-it-works.qmd
├── how-to/
│   ├── deploy-github.qmd
│   └── custom-theme.qmd
└── make.jl
QuartoDocBuilder will automatically:

Create dropdown menus for each section in the navbar
Generate index pages (e.g., tutorials.qmd, explanation.qmd)
Create sidebars for navigation within each section




You can also configure sections via _quartodoc.toml:
[[sections]]
title = "Tutorials"
dir = "tutorials"
order = 1

[[sections]]
title = "Explanation"
dir = "explanation"
order = 2

[[sections]]
title = "How-to Guides"
dir = "how-to"
order = 3
dropdown_limit = 20



By default, sections with fewer than 15 items show as dropdown menus. For sections with many items, the dropdown falls back to linking to an index page.
# This section will always show as a dropdown (up to 50 items)
SectionConfig(
    title = "How-to Guides",
    dir = "how-to",
    dropdown_limit = 50
)

# This section will never show as a dropdown
SectionConfig(
    title = "Examples",
    dir = "examples",
    dropdown = false
)



This very documentation uses multiple sections:

Tutorials - Getting started guides
Explanation - How QuartoDocBuilder works
How-to Guides - Task-oriented guides

Check out the make.jl for the complete configuration.

title: Changelog
text:
Only uses Julia stdlib packages (Markdown, TOML)
No external dependencies required
Minimum Julia version: 1.6





Initial release with pkgdown-like functionality for Julia packages
Configuration system with type-safe QuartoConfig struct
Reference page grouping with pkgdown-style selectors (starts_with, ends_with, matches, contains)
Articles/vignettes system with auto-discovery and navbar dropdowns
NEWS.md parsing and changelog page generation with GitHub issue linking
Light/dark mode toggle with automatic theme pairing (flatly/darkly, cosmo/cyborg, etc.)
Auto-linking of function references in documentation
GitHub Actions workflow generation for automated deployment
Giscus comments integration for reader feedback
Custom theming support (colors, fonts, CSS/SCSS)
TOML configuration file support (_quartodoc.toml)

title: Architecture Overview
text:
QuartoDocBuilder is designed to be modular and extensible. This document explains the internal architecture.




The configuration system provides type-safe structs for all settings:

QuartoConfig - Main configuration struct
SectionConfig - Navbar section configuration
ReferenceGroup - Reference page grouping
ThemeConfig - Theme and appearance settings
FooterConfig - Footer customization




Inspired by R’s pkgdown, selectors allow flexible organization of reference pages:
# Match functions by name patterns
starts_with("process_")  # All functions starting with "process_"
ends_with("_util")       # All functions ending with "_util"
matches(r"^get")         # Regex matching
contains("helper")       # Contains substring



Converts Julia docstrings to Quarto-compatible markdown:

Handles code blocks with proper fencing
Converts admonitions to callout blocks
Preserves formatting and structure




The main build orchestrator:

Generates _quarto.yml configuration
Creates section directories and index files
Generates reference pages for each documented function
Creates navigation structure (navbar, sidebars)




Discovers and organizes content files:

Auto-discovers .qmd files in section directories
Extracts titles and metadata from YAML frontmatter
Sorts by order field or alphabetically





                    ┌─────────────────┐
                    │  QuartoConfig   │
                    └────────┬────────┘
                             │
            ┌────────────────┼────────────────┐
            │                │                │
            ▼                ▼                ▼
    ┌───────────────┐ ┌───────────────┐ ┌───────────────┐
    │  _quarto.yml  │ │   reference/  │ │   sections/   │
    │  (navbar,     │ │   (function   │ │   (tutorials, │
    │   sidebars)   │ │   docs)       │ │   guides)     │
    └───────────────┘ └───────────────┘ └───────────────┘
            │                │                │
            └────────────────┼────────────────┘
                             │
                             ▼
                    ┌─────────────────┐
                    │  Quarto render  │
                    └────────┬────────┘
                             │
                             ▼
                    ┌─────────────────┐
                    │   HTML Site     │
                    └─────────────────┘





You can create custom selector functions:
# Create a selector that matches documented functions only
my_selector = sym -> begin
    obj = getfield(MyModule, sym)
    return obj isa Function && hasmethod(obj, Tuple{})
end



Extend the theme with custom CSS/SCSS:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    custom_css = """
    .my-custom-class {
        color: red;
    }
    """
)




QuartoDocBuilder only depends on Julia standard library:

Markdown - Parsing docstrings
TOML - Configuration files

No external packages required!

title: Advanced Features
text:
This guide covers QuartoDocBuilder’s advanced features for creating comprehensive documentation.


Articles (also called vignettes) are long-form documentation pages for tutorials, guides, and explanations.



Create a directory: docs/articles/
Add .qmd files with YAML frontmatter:

---
title: "My Article"
description: "A detailed guide"
order: 1
---

# My Article

Content goes here...



QuartoDocBuilder automatically discovers articles in docs/articles/:
# Find all articles
articles = discover_articles("docs/articles")

# Find recursively (including subdirectories)
articles = discover_articles_recursive("docs/articles")



If you have an article named after your package (e.g., mypackage.qmd) or named getting-started.qmd, it’s automatically detected:
# Auto-detect "Get Started" article
get_started_path = detect_get_started(MyPackage)



Articles can appear as a dropdown menu in the navbar:
articles = ArticleConfig(
    title = "Guides",
    dropdown = true   # Show as dropdown menu
)
When dropdown = true and you have 10 or fewer articles, they appear directly in a dropdown. With more articles, a link to the articles index is shown instead.



Generate an articles index automatically:
quarto_articles_index(config)
This creates docs/articles.qmd with a Quarto listing of all articles.




QuartoDocBuilder can parse your NEWS.md file and generate a formatted changelog page.


Create NEWS.md in your package root:
# MyPackage 1.2.0 (2024-06-15)

## Features

- Added new `process_data()` function (#42)
- Improved performance by 50% (@contributor)

## Bug Fixes

- Fixed crash when input is empty (#38)
- Corrected documentation typos

## Breaking Changes

- Renamed `old_func()` to `new_func()`

# MyPackage 1.1.0 (2024-03-01)

## Features

- Initial feature set
Supported formats:

# Package 1.0.0 (date) - Package name with version and optional date
# v1.0.0 - Version only
# 1.0.0 - date - Version with date after dash




References are automatically linked:

#123 → Link to issue/PR #123
@username → Link to GitHub user profile
user/repo#456 → Cross-repo issue link

# Example
text = "Fixed bug #42 reported by @contributor"
linked = linkify_github_refs(text, "user/repo")
# "Fixed bug [#42](https://github.com/user/repo/issues/42) reported by [@contributor](https://github.com/contributor)"



The news page is generated automatically when news = true:
config = QuartoConfig(
    # ...
    news = true,
    news_file = "NEWS.md"  # Default
)
quarto_build_site(config)
Or generate it manually:
quarto_news_page(config)
The generated page shows:

Latest version expanded
Older versions in collapsible sections
Categories (Features, Bug Fixes, etc.) as subsections
Automatic GitHub links





QuartoDocBuilder can generate GitHub Actions workflows for automated documentation deployment.


using QuartoDocBuilder

# Modern GitHub Pages deployment
quarto_github_action()

# Traditional gh-pages branch deployment
quarto_github_action_simple(branch="gh-pages")
This creates .github/workflows/docs.yml.



quarto_github_action(
    quarto_version = "pre-release",  # Quarto version
    julia_version = "1",              # Julia version
    output_dir = "site",              # Output directory
    trigger_branches = ["main"]       # Branches that trigger build
)



After generating the workflow:

Push to GitHub
Go to Settings → Pages
Under “Build and deployment”, select GitHub Actions
Your docs will be at https://username.github.io/repo




Use the one-stop setup function:
setup_documentation(MyPackage; repo="user/MyPackage.jl")
This creates:

docs/make.jl - Build script
docs/Project.toml - Dependencies
.github/workflows/docs.yml - CI workflow
Initial documentation structure





QuartoDocBuilder can automatically convert function references in documentation to clickable links.


References in backticks are converted to links:
Use `my_function()` to process data.
Becomes:
Use [`my_function()`](reference/my_function.qmd) to process data.



# Build reference index
index = build_reference_index(MyPackage)

# Auto-link text
text = "Use `my_function()` for processing."
linked = autolink_references(text, index)



Check for references that don’t have documentation:
undefined = find_undefined_references(text, index)
# Returns: ["undefined_func", "missing_func"]






theme = ThemeConfig(
    # ...
    custom_css = """
    /* Custom styles */
    .my-class {
        color: blue;
    }

    .callout-note {
        border-left-color: #007bff;
    }
    """
)



For advanced theming, use SCSS variables:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    # ...
    custom_scss = """
    \$primary: #007bff;
    \$link-color: #28a745;
    \$font-family-sans-serif: "Inter", sans-serif;
    """
)
When custom colors are specified, QuartoDocBuilder generates docs/custom.scss with the variables.



You can also add custom files:

docs/styles.css - Main stylesheet (auto-generated, you can modify)
docs/custom.scss - SCSS variables (auto-generated if custom colors used)







When you add new functions:
quarto_rebuild_reference(MyPackage)
# or
quarto_rebuild_reference(config)



To regenerate everything:
quarto_rebuild_all(MyPackage; repo="user/repo")
# or
quarto_rebuild_all(config)




A typical development workflow:
# Initial setup
setup_documentation(MyPackage; repo="user/MyPackage.jl")

# After adding new functions
quarto_rebuild_reference(MyPackage)

# After changing configuration
quarto_rebuild_all(config)

# Preview changes
# Run: cd docs && quarto preview





QuartoDocBuilder extracts docstrings, so well-written docstrings make better docs:
"""
    my_function(x, y; option=true)

Short description of what the function does.

# Arguments
- `x`: Description of x
- `y`: Description of y
- `option`: What this option controls

# Returns
What the function returns.

# Examples
```julia
result = my_function(1, 2)

# v1.0.0 - Version only
# 1.0.0 - date - Version with date after dash




References are automatically linked:

#123 → Link to issue/PR #123
@username → Link to GitHub user profile
user/repo#456 → Cross-repo issue link

# Example
text = "Fixed bug #42 reported by @contributor"
linked = linkify_github_refs(text, "user/repo")
# "Fixed bug [#42](https://github.com/user/repo/issues/42) reported by [@contributor](https://github.com/contributor)"



The news page is generated automatically when news = true:
config = QuartoConfig(
    # ...
    news = true,
    news_file = "NEWS.md"  # Default
)
quarto_build_site(config)
Or generate it manually:
quarto_news_page(config)
The generated page shows:

Latest version expanded
Older versions in collapsible sections
Categories (Features, Bug Fixes, etc.) as subsections
Automatic GitHub links

title: Advanced Features
text:
QuartoDocBuilder can generate GitHub Actions workflows for automated documentation deployment.


using QuartoDocBuilder

# Modern GitHub Pages deployment
quarto_github_action()

# Traditional gh-pages branch deployment
quarto_github_action_simple(branch="gh-pages")
This creates .github/workflows/docs.yml.



quarto_github_action(
    quarto_version = "pre-release",  # Quarto version
    julia_version = "1",              # Julia version
    output_dir = "site",              # Output directory
    trigger_branches = ["main"]       # Branches that trigger build
)



After generating the workflow:

Push to GitHub
Go to Settings → Pages
Under “Build and deployment”, select GitHub Actions
Your docs will be at https://username.github.io/repo




Use the one-stop setup function:
setup_documentation(MyPackage; repo="user/MyPackage.jl")
This creates:

docs/make.jl - Build script
docs/Project.toml - Dependencies
.github/workflows/docs.yml - CI workflow
Initial documentation structure

title: Advanced Features
text:
QuartoDocBuilder can automatically convert function references in documentation to clickable links.


References in backticks are converted to links:
Use `my_function()` to process data.
Becomes:
Use [`my_function()`](reference/my_function.qmd) to process data.



# Build reference index
index = build_reference_index(MyPackage)

# Auto-link text
text = "Use `my_function()` for processing."
linked = autolink_references(text, index)



Check for references that don’t have documentation:
undefined = find_undefined_references(text, index)
# Returns: ["undefined_func", "missing_func"]

title: Advanced Features
Advanced Features
text:
When you add new functions:
quarto_rebuild_reference(MyPackage)
# or
quarto_rebuild_reference(config)



To regenerate everything:
quarto_rebuild_all(MyPackage; repo="user/repo")
# or
quarto_rebuild_all(config)

title: Advanced Features
text:
A typical development workflow:
# Initial setup
setup_documentation(MyPackage; repo="user/MyPackage.jl")

# After adding new functions
quarto_rebuild_reference(MyPackage)

# After changing configuration
quarto_rebuild_all(config)

# Preview changes
# Run: cd docs && quarto preview

title: Advanced Features
text:
QuartoDocBuilder extracts docstrings, so well-written docstrings make better docs:
"""
    my_function(x, y; option=true)

Short description of what the function does.

# Arguments
- `x`: Description of x
- `y`: Description of y
- `option`: What this option controls

# Returns
What the function returns.

# Examples
```julia
result = my_function(1, 2)

title: Advanced Features
text:
Troubleshooting

Common Issues
“Module not found”: Make sure to activate the docs environment:
using Pkg
Pkg.activate("docs")
Pkg.develop(path=dirname(@__DIR__))
**“_quarto.yml already exists”**: Delete it or use force=true:
quarto_yaml_from_config(config; force=true)
“Julia engine not available”: Install Quarto pre-release for Julia support:
quarto install tinytex  # If needed


Getting Help

GitHub Issues
Quarto Documentation

title: Customize Theme
text:
QuartoDocBuilder supports extensive theme customization through ThemeConfig.


Choose from Bootswatch themes:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "cosmo"  # or flatly, journal, lumen, etc.
)





Theme
Description




flatly
Flat and clean


cosmo
Modern and professional


journal
News/article style


litera
Readable and light


lumen
Bright and cheerful


minty
Fresh green accent


pulse
Purple accent


sandstone
Warm earth tones


yeti
Bootstrap default look







Enable automatic light/dark mode toggle:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    dark_mode = true  # Adds theme toggle, pairs with "darkly"
)
Dark themes are automatically paired:



Light
Dark




flatly
darkly


cosmo
cyborg


journal
slate


lumen
solar


minty
vapor






Override default colors:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    primary = "#007bff",    # Primary brand color
    accent = "#28a745",     # Links and accents
    bg = "#ffffff",         # Background
    fg = "#212529"          # Text color
)



Specify font families:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    font_base = "Open Sans, sans-serif",
    font_heading = "Montserrat, sans-serif",
    font_code = "Fira Code, monospace"
)



Choose a code highlighting theme:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    code_highlight = "github"  # or monokai, dracula, nord, etc.
)



Add custom CSS rules:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    custom_css = """
    /* Custom navbar gradient */
    .navbar {
        background: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%) !important;
    }

    /* Custom code block style */
    pre code {
        border-radius: 8px;
    }

    /* Highlight callouts */
    .callout-note {
        border-left-color: #007bff;
    }
    """
)



For advanced customization, use SCSS:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    custom_scss = """
    $primary: #667eea;
    $link-color: #764ba2;
    $border-radius: 0.5rem;
    """
)



config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "user/MyPackage.jl",

    theme = ThemeConfig(
        bootswatch = "cosmo",
        dark_mode = true,
        primary = "#6366f1",
        accent = "#8b5cf6",
        code_highlight = "nord",
        font_heading = "Inter, sans-serif",
        custom_css = """
        .navbar-brand {
            font-weight: 700;
        }
        """
    )
)



After modifying the theme, rebuild and preview:
julia --project=docs docs/make.jl
cd docs && quarto preview
The preview server will hot-reload CSS changes.

title: Organize Reference Page
text:
By default, QuartoDocBuilder lists all documented functions alphabetically. You can organize them into logical groups using ReferenceGroup.


reference = [
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Core Functions",
        contents = [:main_func, :helper_func, :process_data]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Utilities",
        contents = [:format_output, :validate_input]
    )
]

config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    reference = reference
)



Instead of listing every function, use pattern-based selectors:


Match functions by name prefix:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Data Processing",
    contents = [starts_with("process_")]  # process_data, process_file, etc.
)



Match functions by name suffix:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Utilities",
    contents = [ends_with("_util")]  # format_util, string_util, etc.
)



Use regex patterns:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Getters & Setters",
    contents = [matches(r"^(get|set)_")]  # get_value, set_config, etc.
)



Match substring anywhere in name:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Helper Functions",
    contents = [contains("helper")]  # my_helper, string_helper_func, etc.
)




Mix explicit symbols with selectors:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Data I/O",
    contents = [
        :read_data,              # Explicit symbol
        :write_data,             # Explicit symbol
        starts_with("load_"),    # All load_* functions
        starts_with("save_")     # All save_* functions
    ]
)



Each group can have a description:
ReferenceGroup(
    title = "Configuration",
    desc = "Functions for setting up and configuring the package.",
    contents = [:QuartoConfig, :ThemeConfig, :load_config]
)



reference = [
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Configuration",
        desc = "Types and functions for configuring documentation.",
        contents = [:QuartoConfig, :SectionConfig, :ThemeConfig,
                   :load_config, :default_config]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Site Building",
        desc = "Core functions for generating documentation sites.",
        contents = [:quarto_build_site, starts_with("quarto_")]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Content Selectors",
        desc = "Helpers for organizing reference pages.",
        contents = [:starts_with, :ends_with, :matches, :contains]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Utilities",
        contents = [ends_with("_util"), contains("helper")]
    )
]



If you don’t specify reference, QuartoDocBuilder auto-groups by type:

Functions - All function symbols
Types - All struct/type definitions
Constants - All constant values

# This will auto-group
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    reference = []  # Empty = auto-group
)



Functions are assigned to the first matching group. Order your groups from most specific to most general:
reference = [
    # Specific first
    ReferenceGroup(title = "Core", contents = [:main_func]),

    # Pattern-based second
    ReferenceGroup(title = "Processing", contents = [starts_with("process_")]),

    # Catch-all last
    ReferenceGroup(title = "Other", contents = [matches(r".*")])
]

title: quarto_build_refpage
text:
quarto_build_refpage






docblock






Symbol(x...) -> Symbol

Create a Symbol by concatenating the string representations of the arguments together.

Examples

julia> Symbol("my", "name")
:myname

julia> Symbol("day", 4)
:day4












docblock






Symbol

The type of object used to represent identifiers in parsed julia code (ASTs). Also often used as a name or label to identify an entity (e.g. as a dictionary key). Symbols can be entered using the : quote operator:

julia> :name
:name

julia> typeof(:name)
Symbol

julia> x = 42
42

julia> eval(:x)
42

Symbols can also be constructed from strings or other values by calling the constructor Symbol(x...).
Symbols are immutable and their implementation re-uses the same object for all Symbols with the same name.
Unlike strings, Symbols are “atomic” or “scalar” entities that do not support iteration over characters.

title: QuartoDocBuilder.jl
text:
QuartoDocBuilder.jl
QuartoDocBuilder.jl is a package inspired by R pkgdown. It provides an easy way to generate a website with documentation and vignettes, by creating a Quarto project.
Being powered by Quarto means that deploying to Github pages, customizing the style and many more things are taken for granted. This website doc even has a comment section! Check some examples here and the complete list of options here.
The Quarto website itself is written with Quarto! Check the github repo here to get some inspiration.


How to use
See the tutorials at https://vituri.github.io/QuartoDocBuilder.jl/tutorials.html .

Symbol(x...) -> Symbol

Create a Symbol by concatenating the string representations of the arguments together.

Examples

julia> Symbol("my", "name")
:myname

julia> Symbol("day", 4)
:day4












docblock






Symbol

The type of object used to represent identifiers in parsed julia code (ASTs). Also often used as a name or label to identify an entity (e.g. as a dictionary key). Symbols can be entered using the : quote operator:

julia> :name
:name

julia> typeof(:name)
Symbol

julia> x = 42
42

julia> eval(:x)
42

Symbols can also be constructed from strings or other values by calling the constructor Symbol(x...).
Symbols are immutable and their implementation re-uses the same object for all Symbols with the same name.
Unlike strings, Symbols are “atomic” or “scalar” entities that do not support iteration over characters.

title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
text:
This guide shows how to automatically deploy your documentation to GitHub Pages.


QuartoDocBuilder can generate a GitHub Actions workflow for you:
using QuartoDocBuilder
quarto_github_action()
This creates .github/workflows/documentation.yml.



The generated workflow:

Triggers on pushes to main branch
Installs Julia and Quarto
Builds documentation
Deploys to GitHub Pages

name: Documentation
on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: julia-actions/setup-julia@v1
      - uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/setup@v2

      - name: Build documentation
        run: |
          julia --project=docs -e '
            using Pkg
            Pkg.develop(path=".")
            Pkg.instantiate()
            include("docs/make.jl")
          '
          cd docs && quarto render

      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: docs/site

  deploy:
    needs: build
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
        id: deployment




Go to your repository Settings
Click Pages in the sidebar
Under “Build and deployment”, select GitHub Actions
Push to main to trigger the first build




To use a custom domain:

Add a CNAME file to docs/ with your domain
Configure DNS records for your domain
Enable HTTPS in GitHub Pages settings






Check the Actions log for errors. Common issues:

Missing dependencies in docs/Project.toml
Quarto rendering errors
Julia compilation errors





Ensure the workflow completed successfully
Check that docs/site/ is being uploaded
Wait a few minutes for GitHub to deploy





Verify output_dir = "site" in your config
Check that _quarto.yml is generated correctly

title: Configuration & Customization
text:
QuartoDocBuilder offers extensive customization through the QuartoConfig struct. This guide covers all configuration options.


The main configuration is done through QuartoConfig:
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,        # Required: your module
    repo = "user/MyPackage.jl",     # GitHub repository
    output_dir = "site",            # Output directory

    # Reference page organization
    reference = [...],              # Vector of ReferenceGroup

    # Articles
    articles = ArticleConfig(...),
    get_started = "articles/intro.qmd",

    # News
    news = true,
    news_file = "NEWS.md",

    # Theme
    theme = ThemeConfig(...),

    # Comments
    comments = true,
    giscus_repo = "user/repo",

    # Footer
    footer = FooterConfig(...)
)



The reference page can be organized into groups using ReferenceGroup:
reference = [
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Core Functions",
        desc = "Main package functionality",
        contents = [:main_function, :helper_function]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Utilities",
        contents = [:util_a, :util_b]
    )
]


Instead of listing every function manually, use selector functions:








Selector
Description
Example




starts_with(prefix)
Functions starting with prefix
starts_with("process_")


ends_with(suffix)
Functions ending with suffix
ends_with("_util")


matches(pattern)
Functions matching regex
matches(r"^get")


contains(substring)
Functions containing substring
contains("helper")



Example:
reference = [
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Data Processing",
        desc = "Functions for processing data",
        contents = [
            :main_process,           # Explicit symbol
            starts_with("process_"), # All functions starting with "process_"
            ends_with("_data")       # All functions ending with "_data"
        ]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Getters & Setters",
        contents = [matches(r"^(get|set)_")]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Utilities",
        contents = [contains("util"), contains("helper")]
    )
]



If you don’t specify reference, QuartoDocBuilder auto-groups by type:

Functions - All function symbols
Types - All struct/type definitions
Constants - All constant values







theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",       # Bootswatch theme name
    dark_mode = true,            # Enable light/dark toggle
    primary = "#446E9B",         # Primary color (optional)
    bg = "",                     # Background color (optional)
    fg = "",                     # Foreground color (optional)
    accent = "",                 # Accent/link color (optional)
    font_base = "",              # Base font family (optional)
    font_heading = "",           # Heading font family (optional)
    font_code = "",              # Code font family (optional)
    code_highlight = "github",   # Syntax highlighting theme
    custom_css = "",             # Additional CSS
    custom_scss = ""             # Additional SCSS variables
)



Light themes (automatically paired with dark variants):



Light Theme
Dark Variant




flatly
darkly


cosmo
cyborg


journal
slate


litera
superhero


lumen
solar


minty
vapor


pulse
quartz


sandstone
slate


yeti
slate






Add custom colors using CSS color values:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    primary = "#007bff",         # Custom primary color
    accent = "#28a745",          # Custom link color
    custom_css = """
    .navbar {
        background: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%);
    }
    """
)



When dark_mode = true, QuartoDocBuilder:

Adds a theme toggle button to the navbar
Automatically pairs your light theme with a matching dark theme
Respects user’s system preference

To disable:
theme = ThemeConfig(
    bootswatch = "flatly",
    dark_mode = false    # No toggle, always light theme
)




footer = FooterConfig(
    left = "Copyright 2024 [Author](https://author.com)",
    center = "",
    right = "Built with QuartoDocBuilder.jl"
)
Markdown is supported in footer text.



For complex configurations, use a _quartodoc.toml file:
[project]
repo = "user/MyPackage.jl"
output_dir = "site"
comments = true

[execution]
freeze = "auto"
cache = true

[[reference]]
title = "Core Functions"
desc = "Main package functionality"
contents = ["main_func", "starts_with:process_"]

[[reference]]
title = "Utilities"
contents = ["ends_with:_util"]

[articles]
title = "Tutorials"
dropdown = true
get_started = "articles/intro.qmd"

[theme]
bootswatch = "flatly"
dark_mode = true
code_highlight = "github"

[footer]
left = "Copyright 2024"
right = "Built with QuartoDocBuilder.jl"
Load and use it:
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Load config from file
config = load_config("_quartodoc.toml")

# Set the module (can't be in TOML)
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    # Other fields from loaded config are preserved
    repo = config.repo,
    reference = config.reference,
    theme = config.theme,
    # ...
)

quarto_build_site(config)



articles = ArticleConfig(
    title = "Tutorials",           # Navbar text
    desc = "Learn how to use...",  # Index page description
    dir = "articles",              # Directory name
    dropdown = true                # Show as dropdown in navbar
)


Add a prominent “Get Started” link in the navbar:
config = QuartoConfig(
    # ...
    get_started = "articles/getting-started.qmd"
)




Enable reader comments using Giscus:
config = QuartoConfig(
    # ...
    comments = true,
    giscus_repo = "user/repo"  # Repository with Discussions enabled
)
Requirements:

Enable GitHub Discussions on your repository
Install the Giscus app
Set giscus_repo to your repository




Here’s a full configuration example:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",

    reference = [
        ReferenceGroup(
            title = "Data I/O",
            desc = "Functions for reading and writing data",
            contents = [starts_with("read_"), starts_with("write_")]
        ),
        ReferenceGroup(
            title = "Processing",
            desc = "Data processing functions",
            contents = [starts_with("process_"), contains("transform")]
        ),
        ReferenceGroup(
            title = "Utilities",
            contents = [ends_with("_util"), ends_with("_helper")]
        )
    ],

    articles = ArticleConfig(
        title = "Guides",
        dropdown = true
    ),
    get_started = "articles/quickstart.qmd",

    news = true,

    theme = ThemeConfig(
        bootswatch = "cosmo",
        dark_mode = true,
        code_highlight = "monokai"
    ),

    comments = true,
    giscus_repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",

    footer = FooterConfig(
        left = "MIT License",
        right = "[Source Code](https://github.com/myuser/MyPackage.jl)"
    )
)

quarto_build_site(config)

title: Getting Started
text:
QuartoDocBuilder.jl is a Julia package that generates beautiful documentation websites for your Julia packages using Quarto. It’s inspired by R’s pkgdown and provides similar features.


Before you begin, make sure you have:

Julia 1.6+ installed
Quarto installed (download here)
A Julia package with documented functions (docstrings)




Add QuartoDocBuilder to your package’s documentation environment:
# In your package directory
julia> using Pkg
julia> Pkg.activate("docs")
julia> Pkg.add("QuartoDocBuilder")
Or add it to your docs/Project.toml:
[deps]
QuartoDocBuilder = "164f4f01-dadb-4e86-a767-9a3bba57cbbb"





Create a file docs/make.jl with:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Build documentation with default settings
quarto_build_site(MyPackage; repo="username/MyPackage.jl")



julia --project=docs docs/make.jl
This generates the following structure:
docs/
├── _quarto.yml       # Quarto configuration
├── index.qmd         # Home page (from README.md)
├── reference.qmd     # API reference index
├── reference/        # Individual function docs
│   ├── my_function.qmd
│   └── ...
├── tutorials.qmd     # Tutorials index
├── tutorials/        # Tutorial files
└── styles.css        # Custom CSS



cd docs
quarto preview
This starts a local server at http://localhost:4200 where you can see your documentation.



cd docs
quarto render
The rendered HTML site will be in docs/site/ by default.




QuartoDocBuilder automatically creates:








Component
Source
Description




Home page
README.md
Your package’s README becomes the landing page


Reference pages
Docstrings
Every documented function gets its own page


Reference index
Auto-generated
Lists all functions with descriptions


Tutorials
docs/tutorials/
Your tutorial files (you create these)


Styles
Auto-generated
Professional CSS styling


Navigation
Auto-generated
Navbar with links to all sections






Create .qmd files in docs/tutorials/:
---
title: "My First Tutorial"
---

# Welcome

This is a tutorial for MyPackage...





Generate a workflow file:
using QuartoDocBuilder
quarto_github_action()
Then:

Push to GitHub
Go to Settings > Pages
Select “GitHub Actions” as the source




cd docs
quarto render
# Upload docs/site/ to your hosting





Configuration Guide: Learn how to customize your documentation
Advanced Features: Articles, news pages, auto-linking, and more
Reference: Full API documentation




Here’s a complete example docs/make.jl:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Simple usage
quarto_build_site(MyPackage;
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = "flatly"
)

# Or with full configuration
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = ThemeConfig(
        bootswatch = "flatly",
        dark_mode = true

text:
Create a file docs/make.jl with:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Build documentation with default settings
quarto_build_site(MyPackage; repo="username/MyPackage.jl")



julia --project=docs docs/make.jl
This generates the following structure:
docs/
├── _quarto.yml       # Quarto configuration
├── index.qmd         # Home page (from README.md)
├── reference.qmd     # API reference index
├── reference/        # Individual function docs
│   ├── my_function.qmd
│   └── ...
├── tutorials.qmd     # Tutorials index
├── tutorials/        # Tutorial files
└── styles.css        # Custom CSS



cd docs
quarto preview
This starts a local server at http://localhost:4200 where you can see your documentation.



cd docs
quarto render
The rendered HTML site will be in docs/site/ by default.

title: Getting Started
text:
Here’s a complete example docs/make.jl:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Simple usage
quarto_build_site(MyPackage;
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = "flatly"
)

# Or with full configuration
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = ThemeConfig(
        bootswatch = "flatly",
        dark_mode = true
    ),
    comments = true
)
quarto_build_site(config)






Pro Tip



Run quarto_build_refpage(MyPackage) after adding new functions to update the reference index without rebuilding everything.

title: Docstring Processing
text:
QuartoDocBuilder automatically extracts and formats Julia docstrings for Quarto.




Julia stores documentation in Base.Docs.meta(). QuartoDocBuilder iterates through all documented symbols:
# Get all documented symbols from a module
symbols = get_objects_from_module(MyModule)



Each docstring is parsed and converted to Quarto-compatible markdown:

Code blocks → Wrapped in proper fences with language hints
Headers → Adjusted to appropriate levels
Admonitions → Converted to Quarto callout blocks
Examples → Preserved with #| eval: false to prevent execution




Each documented function gets its own page in docs/reference/:
docs/reference/
├── my_function.qmd
├── another_function.qmd
└── MyType.qmd






"""
    my_function(x)

Example:
```julia
result = my_function(42)
““”

Becomes a Quarto code block with `eval: false`.

### Admonitions

```julia
"""
!!! warning "Performance Note"
    This function is O(n²) for large inputs.
"""
Becomes a Quarto callout:
::: {.callout-warning title="Performance Note"}
This function is O(n²) for large inputs.
:::



Functions with multiple methods have all signatures documented:
"""
    process(x::Int)
    process(x::String)

Process different types of input.
"""






Use ReferenceGroup to organize the reference page:
reference = [
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Core Functions",
        desc = "Main package functionality",
        contents = [:main_func, :helper_func]
    ),
    ReferenceGroup(
        title = "Utilities",
        contents = [starts_with("util_")]
    )
]



The reference index shows short descriptions extracted from the first line of each docstring.







First line should be a brief summary
Signature should be included
Arguments section for parameters
Examples for usage

"""
    process_data(input; normalize=true)

Process input data with optional normalization.

# Arguments
- `input`: The data to process
- `normalize`: Whether to normalize output (default: true)

# Returns
A processed DataFrame.

# Examples
```julia
result = process_data(my_data)
result = process_data(my_data, normalize=false)
““” ```

title: Getting Started
text:
QuartoDocBuilder.jl is a Julia package that generates beautiful documentation websites for your Julia packages using Quarto. It’s inspired by R’s pkgdown and provides similar features.


Before you begin, make sure you have:

Julia 1.6+ installed
Quarto installed (download here)
A Julia package with documented functions (docstrings)




Add QuartoDocBuilder to your package’s documentation environment:
# In your package directory
julia> using Pkg
julia> Pkg.activate("docs")
julia> Pkg.add("QuartoDocBuilder")





Create a file docs/make.jl with:
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Build documentation with default settings
quarto_build_site(MyPackage; repo="username/MyPackage.jl")



julia --project=docs docs/make.jl



cd docs
quarto preview
This starts a local server at http://localhost:4200 where you can see your documentation.



cd docs
quarto render
The rendered HTML site will be in docs/site/ by default.
